questions.prompt: What notation indicates a discrete-time signal?
questions.explanation: Brackets [n] indicate discrete-time signals, defined only at integer values. Parentheses (t) indicate continuous-time signals defined for all real t values. This is a universal convention in signals and systems.

questions.prompt: A continuous-time signal is defined for:
questions.explanation: Continuous-time signals x(t) are defined for every real value of the independent variable tâ€”you can zoom in infinitely and the signal remains defined. Discrete signals are only at integers.

questions.prompt: What is the Nyquist sampling rate for a 10 kHz signal?
questions.explanation: The Nyquist theorem states: sample at fs > 2Ã—fmax. For a 10 kHz signal, Nyquist rate = 2 Ã— 10 kHz = 20 kHz. Sampling below this causes aliasing.

Aliasing occurs when sampling below Nyquist rate (fs < 2Ã—fmax), causing high frequencies to 'fold' and appear as lower frequencies. High sampling rate prevents aliasing. DC and periodicity are unrelated.
An Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC) converts continuous-time analog signals to discrete-time digital signals through sampling and quantization. DAC does the reverse.

questions.prompt: CD audio uses 44.1 kHz sampling because:
options: Human hearing is up to ~20 kHz
questions.correctAnswer: Human hearing is up to ~20 kHz
questions.explanation: Human hearing ranges up to ~20 kHz. Per Nyquist, we need fs > 40 kHz. CD uses 44.1 kHz which exceeds this requirement and provides a safety margin for anti-aliasing filters.

questions.prompt: The value x[1.5] for a discrete signal is:
questions.explanation: Discrete-time signals x[n] are only defined at integer indices. x[1.5] is undefined (not zero!)â€”the signal simply doesn't exist between sample points. This is fundamental to discrete signal definition.
An anti-aliasing filter (lowpass filter) is applied before sampling to remove frequency components above Nyquist, preventing them from folding back and corrupting the signal.
Ts is the sampling periodâ€”the time interval between consecutive samples, measured in seconds. Sampling frequency fs = 1/Ts. This is standard notation in DSP.
